author: Abril Escalante
title: Jorge Rey anuncia el mayor cambio de tiempo y media España se echa a temblar - La Opinión de Murcia
text: Jorge Rey anuncia el mayor cambio de tiempo y media España se echa a temblar El joven cabañuelo ha explicado qué es lo que cree que va a pasar en los próximos días antes de Semana Santa Las calles ya empiezan a oler a incienso y se ven los primeros nazarenos cruzando los pasos de peatones: la [Semana Santa](/comunidad/2024/03/21/hoteles-costa-region-esperan-ocupacion-99753672.html) ya está en todos y cada uno de los rincones de España y eso solo puede significar que aumenta la preocupación generla por el tiempo que va a hacer durante los próximos días en los que, quien más quien menos, celebrará las fiestas religiosas más importantes de nuestro pís. Todo el mundo comienza a mirar al cielo y a preguntarse qué ocurrirá y, en este contexto, el famoso aspirante a meteorólogo Jorge Rey ha llegado con un paquete de respuesas bajo el brazo. Los primeros meses de 2024 se han caracterizado por un patrón meteorológico inusual: tanto enero como febrero han estado marcados por temperaturas mucho más cálidas de lo habitual y unas mínimas por encima de la media,además de una notable ausencia de precipitaciones en muchas regiones que ha dado lugar a que se activen los protocolos de sequía en comunidades autónomas como Andalucía o Cataluña. Jorge Rey avisa de un cambio en el tiempo Pero las anomalías no se detuvieron con la llegada del mes de marzo, que ha estado protagonizado por un clima mayr mente seco y temperaturas suaves en buena parte de España. No obstante, nos acercamos a Semana Santa y Jorge Rey ya ha anunciado que se avecina un importante cambio en las condiciones climáticas. Según su ojo clínico, se espera que las lluvias y la tormenta irrumpan durante los días laborales de la Semana Santa, contrastando con el clima cálido y seco que ha protagonizado los meses anteriores. El cambio drástico que ha anunciado Jorge Rey se puede atribuir a distintos motivos, incluídos fenómenos como la DANA y la variabilidad habitual del clima en estas fechas. En concreto respecto a la DANA Jorge Rey ha previsto que esta se sitúe sobre el archipiélago canario, desencadenando importantes tormentas y precipitaciones que podrían incluso alcanzar la Península, que se vería afectada a su vez por un descenso de las temperaturas que facilitaría la entrada de nieves en las montañas. El cambio de tiempo que anuncia Jorge Rey cae como un jarro de agua fría entre todas aquellas personas que tenían planificadas sus actividades al aire libre durante Semana Santa, o bien entre los devotos que sabiendo la importancia de la lluvia no pueden dejar de lamentarse por el impedimento de rendir homenaje a imágenes de culto. author: MENAFN
title: Mobile Phone Exports At Rs 75,000 Cr Till Nov, On Way To Cross Rs 1,24,000 Cr In FY24 | MENAFN.COM
text:
( MENAFN - IANS) New Delhi, Dec 31 (IANS) Riding on the local manufacturing growth, mobile phone exports from the country have surpassed $9 billion (more than Rs 75,000 crore) from April to November in the current fiscal year, industry data showed on Sunday.
This stupendous growth is compared to $6.2 billion (Over Rs 50,000 crore) during the same period last year, according to the India Cellular and Electronics Association (ICEA).
Led by Apple, India is set to cross $15 billion (over Rs 1,24,000 crore) in mobile phone exports in the current fiscal year, posting a growth of 35 per cent over the last fiscal year.
The country is now the second-biggest manufacturing hub for mobile phones due to heavy investment from original equipment manufacturers, original design manufacturers and companies dealing in components and parts.
“The mobile phone export juggernaut continues, riding on the tremendous growth in mobile phone exports, which have crossed Rs. 75,000 crore during April-November of the current fiscal year. Overall electronics exports have also grown by 28 per cent to Rs. 1,46,584 crore,” said the industry's apex body.
During FY2022-23, out of $23.6 billion of electronics exports, the share of mobile phones accounted for $11.1 billion. Whereas, out of the projected $26 billion in electronics exports, mobile phones are expected to reach $15 billion in FY23-24.
“This year, the mobile phone exports are anticipated to account for about 58 per cent of the overall electronics exports in FY23-24, compared to around 47 per cent in the previous fiscal year,” the ICEA informed.
Apple is aiming to manufacture more than 50 million iPhones in India per year, as it aims to shift some of the production out from China. The tech giant aims to achieve the target within the next two to three years, with additional tens of millions of units planned after that, according to reports.
From Apple to Foxconn, the companies are aiming to leverage domestic capabilities to achieve supply chain diversification and scale up production by manufacturing in the country.
--IANS
na/prw

author: Le Dauphiné Libéré
title: Savoie. Avalanches : risque très élevé ce vendredi
text:
Savoie Avalanches : risque très élevé ce vendredi
Le bulletin “Météo montagne Alpes du Nord” alerte, ce vendredi 3 janvier, sur un risque d’avalanche très élevé, coté 4 sur une échelle de 5, sur les secteurs Beaufortain, Haute-Tarentaise, Vanoise, et Maurienne. Les autres secteurs de la zone montagne des Pays de Savoie (Chablais, Aravis, Mont-Blanc, Haute-Maurienne, Chartreuse, Belledonne, Grandes-Rousses) sont en risque 3, ce qui, rappelons-le, signifie un risque “marqué” et non moyen. Seul le massif des Bauges reste en risque limité.
Une neige friable
Les chutes de neige de la nuit ont pu atteindre une vingtaine de centimètres en altitude. De nombreuses stations ont d’ailleurs déclenché leurs plans de déclenchement préventif ce vendredi. Hors des domaines skiables, la neige la plus récente reste en plaques friables, d’autant qu’elle s’est déposée sur la couche précédente, souvent encore poudreuse.
Les prévisions ne sont guère meilleures pour samedi, avant un épisode de redoux, au cours duquel la pluie pourrait contribuer à stabiliser le manteau neigeux.

author: @CNBC
title: Taekwondo reimagined: How VR is upgrading a 2,000-year-old martial art
text:
Virtual taekwondo is rewriting the rules of competition by combining ancient martial arts with cutting-edge technology. CNBC explores how this VR-powered sport is attracting a new generation of athletes. 08:34 Thu, Jan 23 2025 5:00 PM EST When you think of taekwondo, you might picture a certain physique or skill set, but imagine a version of the sport that anyone, regardless of age, size, or background, can compete in virtually.
In a collaboration between World Taekwondo and Singaporean tech and gaming company Refract Technologies, virtual taekwondo (VTKD) allows athletes to experience the intensity of sparring without the physical contact.
Athletes wear headsets, body sensors, and handheld controllers to spar in a virtual arena, with every move tracked and replicated in real time.
"What's exciting about virtual taekwondo is that it's a real sport" said Ng Chong Geng, Refract Technologies founder, in an interview with CNBC's Converge . "You have to exert yourself physically, and anyone who has tried it will tell you it's exhausting after just three rounds"
What makes virtual taekwondo unique is its inclusivity. The sport levels the playing field by eliminating the traditional barriers of age, size, and gender.
"We could have athletes of all shapes and sizes, fighting together in the same category," said Jin-Bang Yang, a former taekwondo champion and World Taekwondo council member. "It's a totally new area in taekwondo."
The vision behind virtual taekwondo is to both advance the global popularity of the sport and to attract a new generation of athletes. By blending ancient traditions with modern technology, the virtual version offers an exciting glimpse into the future of competitive martial arts.
To learn more about how technology is shaping the future of taekwondo, watch the video above.
For information on CNBC's Converge Live event which takes place in Singapore 12-13 March 2025, click here .

author: Blake Hansen
title: Cold and snowy: Friday brings lake-effect and travel hazards
text:
MICHIGAN, USA — Old Man Winter is here to stay to kick off January, with consistent cold temperatures and periodic opportunities of snow.
Friday’s forecast revolves around a flare-up of lake-effect snow, which will bring some impact around West Michigan. As a result, a [13 Weather Impact Alert](http://www.wzzm.com/weather) has been issued for the expectation of localized snow accumulation and resultant varying travel impacts.
FRIDAY
Lake-effect snow will pick up throughout the early hours of Friday, with tricky travel expected for the morning commute in spots. Lake-effect will be commonplace throughout the entirety of Friday, before gradually waning in coverage and intensity Friday night into Saturday morning.
Snowfall of 1-4" is expected near and westward of US-131 by the end of Friday, but the strongest bands of lake-effect may produce locally higher amounts. The greatest potential for localized higher amounts will be the snowbelts off a northwest wind, which includes portions of Ottawa, Allegan, western Barry, and northern Van Buren and Kalamazoo counties. Another sweet spot for localized higher amounts is near US-10, primarily Mason, Lake, and northern Oceana and Newaygo counties.
Those outside the steadiest lake-effect bands will likely remain on the lower end of the snowfall range. This includes a fair chunk of Kent Co., which isn't a favorable spot for consistent lake-effect snow bands off a northwest wind. Further east of US-131, across Montcalm and Ionia counties, less than 1" of snow is expected.
Impacts will be mostly confined to varying travel conditions, with quick reductions of visibility expected in the heaviest snow bands. Temperatures remaining in the 20s Friday will cause untreated roads to become slick and snow-covered. As always, this time of year, extra time and distance is the best course of action on the roads.
A Winter Weather Advisory will be in effect from 4 a.m. until 7 p.m. Friday from the National Weather Service for much of West Michigan.
WEEKEND & NEXT WEEK
Lake-effect snow will linger into the start of the weekend, but impacts will be limited to none as the coverage and intensity of the snow diminishes throughout Saturday. The weekend will end on a cold, but quiet note.
Temperatures will remain colder than average through the weekend and into next week, with daytime highs in the 20s and nighttime lows in the 10s. It isn’t record cold by any means, but it’ll be consistent through the second week of January, potentially beyond.
Have a 30-second video or photo to share? We'd love to share it with everyone! Share your images by texting your name and location to 616.559.1310 or email to [Weather@13OnYourSide.com](mailto:weather@13onyourside.com) or post it to our [13OnYourSide Facebook Page](https://www.facebook.com/13ONYOURSIDE/)
